results.title: China tour
results.creator_credit: Si Tuan Lieng, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Si Tuan Lieng and his wife are retirees and have recently made an overseas trip to China. In this story he talks about his life and family, their integration into Australian society since they left Vietnam over 26 years ago and highlights of their holiday in China.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Si Tuan Lieng, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Little journey
results.creator_credit: Keith Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith remembers little of his early years - separated from his parents and living with his grandparents. His father had been sent to a Re-education Camp and his mother had moved away. On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Nguyen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Keith remembers little of his early years - separated from his parents and living with his grandparents. His father had been sent to a Re-education Camp and his mother had moved away. On his father’s release from the Camp the family was reunited and several years later they escaped from the hardships of Vietnam to seek a better life in Australia.

results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. results.title: I left my country
results.creator_credit: Joseph Xuan-Minh Le, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1982 Joseph fled from Vietnam and its Communist regime finally arriving in Australia in 1983 as a refugee. He tells of his journey, of leaving family behind, his resettlement in Australia and how seven years later he was finally able to bring his family to Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joseph Xuan-Minh Le, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
results.description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film Faces consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Each subject is framed in close-up and filmed for roughly 25 seconds at a time. Variously self-conscious, serious, nonchalant, curious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
description_for_label:
Sue Ford’s experimental film Faces consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Each subject is framed in close-up and filmed for roughly 25 seconds at a time. Variously self-conscious, serious, nonchalant, curious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Free Willy 2: the adventure home
results.creator_credit: Dwight Little, Jennie Lew-Tugend, Lauren Shuler, Donner Productions and Shuler-Donner
results.brief_description: Jesse is reunited with his Orca friend Willy who has rejoined his family in the wild. Willy becomes trapped by an oil spill fire and Jesse is determined to rescue Willy even if it means risking his own life. Action packed adventure with superb photography, this is a film to be shared by all the family and lovers of whales.

results.title: Crackerjack
results.creator_credit: Paul Moloney, Mick Molloy, Stephen Luby, A Million Monkeys, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Macquarie Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In this laconic Australian comedy an immature thirty-something male discovers something of life when he becomes involved with an ailing local lawn bowls club under threat of closure at the hands of mercenary developers. Mick Molloy (who co-wrote the film with brother Richard) plays Jack, a shabby and exploitative ill-mannered oaf, whose interest in being a member of the club begins and ends with the cheap inner-city parking it provides. When the elderly members of the club call upon him to play the game or forfeit his membership, Jack soon learns lessons in humility, a love of the game and respect for his elderly companions. With a broad comic tone, Australian idiosyncrasies (albeit familiar ones) - excessive swearing, drinking, smoking and jokes about the sexuality of octogenarians - abound. The gender roles are well defined; women in charge of baking, whilst mateship and honour are the ideals to which men aspire. Like “The Castle” (Rob Sitch, 1997) this film embraces the classic David versus Goliath structure, as the morally sound little man faces an evil corporate developer seeking to undermine a certain spirit and camaraderie of society. Melbourne comedian Judith Lucy plays Nance, a local reporter who becomes concerned for the future of the club and forms a romantic attachment to Jack. Also stars Samuel Johnson.
